journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Candida albicans suppression of neutrophil reactive nitrogen species is rescued by host Hif-1α in vivo

article-meta.aff: 1The Bateson Centre, School of Medicine and Population Health, University of Sheffield, Beech Hill Road, Sheffield, S10 2RX, UK
2The School of Biosciences, University of Sheffield, Firth Court, Western Bank, Sheffield, S10 2TN, UK

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Candida spp. cause 750,000 cases per annum of invasive disease worldwide, with up to a 50% mortality rate. Poor efficacy of current antifungals, lack of vaccines and rising antifungal resistance rates point towards an urgent need to develop new therapies. Candida albicans is a human commensal fungus that can cause life-threatening invasive infection in immunocompromised individuals. C. albicans is able to manipulate host macrophages and neutrophils to escape phagosomal killing and has previously been shown to suppress reactive nitrogen species (RNS) production in vitro. However, the effects of C. albicans on RNS in vivo and the molecular and cellular mechanisms involved remain unclear. Using a zebrafish model, we aimed to characterise RNS suppression by C. albicans in vivo. We demonstrate that C. albicans suppressed neutrophil RNS both proximally and distally to the infection site in a partially active process, with heat-killed C. albicans not reducing RNS to the same extent as live fungi. Using a car1Δ mutant, we show that fungal arginase is partially responsible for the reduction in neutrophil RNS. Stabilisation of Hif-1α, a transcription factor with a key role in immune regulation, rescued neutrophil RNS production during C. albicans infection, leading to improved infection outcomes. The protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation was neutrophil- and nitric oxide synthase-dependent. Together, these data demonstrate that Hif-1α stabilisation can restore the neutrophil RNS response in C. albicans infection, leading to improved infection outcomes, highlighting the potential of targeting Hif-1α and RNS in host directed therapies against fungal infections.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Candida albicans is a commensal fungus, colonising 70% of healthy individuals (Witherden et al., 2017), which can cause superficial mucosal infections with negligible mortality. However, C. albicans can also act as an opportunistic pathogen capable of causing life-threatening, invasive disease in immunocompromised individuals and neonates (Witherden et al., 2017; Flores-Maldonado et al., 2019; Pellon, Sadeghi Nasab and Moyes, 2020). Candida species are the 4th most common nosocomial infection in the USA and account for up to 22% of health-care-associated bloodstream infections (Pfaller and Diekema, 2010; Magill et al., 2014). There are approximately 750,000 cases of severe candidiasis worldwide per year and the estimated mortality rate is around 50% (Bongomin et al., 2017; WHO, 2022). This high mortality, combined with the lack of fungal vaccines and rising rates of antifungal resistance, has resulted in C. albicans being designated as a critical priority fungal pathogen, with urgent research into new alternative therapies required (WHO, 2022).

C. albicans infections are initially detected by pattern recognition receptors, including Toll-like receptors, C-type lectin receptors and the Rig-I like receptor, MDA-5, resulting in a downstream pro-inflammatory response and innate immune cell recruitment (reviewed in Burgess, Condliffe and Elks, 2022). Although many immune cell types are recruited to the sites of C. albicans infection, neutrophils are one of the most potent killers of C. albicans and neutropenic patients are particularly at risk of invasive disease (Uzun et al., 2001; Brown, 2011). Candidalysin, produced by hyphal C. albicans, is a particularly strong stimulator of CXCL1-mediated neutrophil recruitment (Drummond et al., 2019). Following recruitment, neutrophils have multiple mechanisms of eliminating C. albicans, including the production of reactive oxygen (ROS) and nitrogen (RNS) species (Winterbourn et al., 2006). Inhibition of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) leads to increased mortality in mouse models of C. albicans infections, showing the importance of RNS mediated fungicidal activity (Tillmann, Gow and Brown, 2011; Wagener et al., 2017; Navarathna, Lionakis and Roberts, 2019).

C. albicans has a variety of mechanisms that can subvert the host innate immune response (Luo et al., 2013). Additionally, C. albicans’ ability to rapidly adapt to changes in environmental pH, metabolic flexibility and a robust stress response allows colonisation of a wide range of niches within the host (Mayer, Wilson and Hube, 2013). The morphotype yeast-to-hyphal transition is essential for host tissue invasion and limits innate immune sensing of C. albicans via masking of β-glucan (Gantner, Simmons and Underhill, 2005; van der Graaf et al., 2005). C. albicans can suppress ROS and RNS production by macrophages in vitro (Wellington, Dolan and Krysan, 2009) with an, as yet, unidentified C. albicans secreted compound responsible for RNS inhibition in murine macrophages (Collette, Zhou and Lorenz, 2014). However, there is currently a lack of in vivo observations on the effects of C. albicans on RNS and little is known about the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying RNS suppression and whether it is possible to rescue this with potential therapeutic application.

Hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) proteins are important regulators of cellular responses to hypoxia, innate immunity and inflammation (McGettrick and O’Neill, 2020). In hypoxic conditions, HIF-1α proteins are stabilised, allowing entry into the nucleus, where they form heterodimers with HIF-1β. Consequent transcription of target genes regulate cellular metabolism, proliferation, migration, differentiation, angiogenesis and pro-inflammatory mediators (Krzywinska and Stockmann, 2018; Hammond, Lewis and Elks, 2020). HIF-1α stabilisation is associated with increased neutrophil survival, via NF-κB and promotes neutrophil extracellular trap formation (Walmsley et al., 2005; McInturff et al., 2012). We have previously shown that stabilisation of Hif-1α increases neutrophil RNS output, which is protective against Mycobacterium marinum infection in vivo (Elks et al., 2013). Therefore, Hif-1α stabilisation represents a potential host directed therapy to target neutrophil RNS during fungal infections, such as C. albicans.

Zebrafish are a highly tractable in vivo model system to investigate the behaviours of innate immune cells during infection (Torraca and Mostowy, 2018). Zebrafish larvae are transparent, allowing the use of innate immune transgenic lines to directly observe neutrophil behaviours and interactions with pathogens (Lam et al., 2004; Renshaw et al., 2006). Adaptive immunity does not mature until 4 to 6 weeks post fertilisation, whereas innate immune cells are present from early larval stages, allowing examination of innate immune responses to infections without the presence of adaptive immunity (Lam et al., 2004). Several infection sites have been used in zebrafish to model C. albicans infection, including localised infection into the hindbrain ventricle and systemic infection via injection into the caudal vein, allowing neutrophil behaviours to be observed to better our understanding of host-C. albicans interactions in an in vivo context (Bergeron et al., 2017; Gratacap et al., 2017; Seman et al., 2018).

Here, we show that C. albicans infection suppressed neutrophil RNS in zebrafish. RNS suppression by C. albicans was shown to occur both locally and distally to the infection site, and was a partially active process, with heat-killed C. albicans having a reduced effect on neutrophil RNS. Fungal arginase (car1) plays a role in RNS reduction, with a car1Δ mutant having a reduced effect on neutrophil RNS. Furthermore, we show that it is possible to restore host RNS production via Hif-1α stabilisation, enhancing host control of C. albicans infection. Together, this work highlights Hif-1α and RNS as potential targets for host directed therapies against invasive C. albicans infections.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: Zebrafish were handled in accordance with Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986, under Project Licenses P1A4A7A5E and PP7684817. Ethical approval was granted by the University of Sheffield Local Ethical Review Panel.

sec.title: Zebrafish
sec.p: Zebrafish were maintained in Home Office approved facilities in Biological Services Unit (BSU) aquaria at the University of Sheffield, in accordance with standard protocols and local animal welfare regulations. Adult fish were maintained at 28°C with a 14/10 hour light/dark cycle. Embryos were maintained at 28 °C with a 14/10 hour light/dark cycle in 1X E3 medium (E3 60X stock: 5.0 mM NaCl, 0.17 mM KCl, 0.33 mM CaCl2, 0.33 mM MgSO4; diluted to 1X in distilled water) with 10-5% Methylene Blue (Sigma-Aldrich). Methylene Blue was added to prevent fungal growth. The following zebrafish strains were used: nacre (wild type), Tg(mpx:GFP)i114 (Renshaw et al., 2006), Tg(lyz:nfsB.mCherry)sh260 (Buchan et al., 2019), Tg(mpeg:nlsClover)sh436 (Bernut et al., 2019).

sec.title: Fungal Strains
sec.p: Several C. albicans strains were used in this study (Table 1). C. albicans was initially grown on YPD (4001022, MP Bio) plates at 28°C for 48 hours, then transferred to overnight liquid culture in YPD broth in a shaking incubator at 30°C at 200 rpm.

sec.title: RNA Injections
sec.p: Embryos were injected with dominant active hif-1αb variant RNA (DA1) or dominant negative hif-1αb variant RNA at the one-cell stage, as previously described (Elks et al., 2011). Phenol Red (PR; Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a vehicle control.

sec.title: Morpholino Injections
sec.p: A csf3r morpholino (Gene Tools) was used to deplete neutrophil populations. A standard control morpholino (Gene Tools) used as a negative control. The antisense morpholino oligonucleotide sequences were: csf3r – 5’-GAAGCACAAGCGAGACGGATGCCAT-3’; control – 5’-CCTCTTACCTCAGTTACAATTTATA-3’.

sec.title: F0 CRISPR-Cas9 Knockdown (CRISPant)
sec.p: Two sgRNAs were designed to target the ATG/first exon of nos2a and nos2b to knockdown iNOS and RNS production. Efficacy of knockdown of RNS production was functionally validated by anti-nitrotyrosine staining. Tyrosinase (tyr) sgRNA was used as a negative control (Isles et al., 2019). The target sequences were: nos2a – 5’-TTTCTCATTTTCAATGATAG-3’; nos2b – 5’-GTTCGCTCTTGTGAGTGACC-3’; tyr – 5’-CCTGACCTCCTGAAGACCCC-3’. 25μM sgRNA was co-injected with tracrRNA, 1:2 diluted Cas9 and phenol red.

sec.title: C. albicans Infections
sec.p: Overnight C. albicans cultures were washed 3 times in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and counted on a haemocytometer. Washed cultures were resuspended in 10% PVP (polyvinylpyrrolidone; Calbiochem) to achieve the desired inoculation. Infection dose for systemic caudal vein infections were 100 colony forming units (cfu) or 200 cfu. Infection dose for localised hindbrain infections was 20 cfu. C. albicans was heat-killed by incubation in a heat block at 65°C for 1 hour (Panpetch et al., 2017). To denature fungal proteins, C. albicans was boiled at 105°C for 5 minutes.

For survival curves, zebrafish survival was monitored daily and dead zebrafish were removed from the Petri dish. Death was determined by a lack of heartbeat/circulation or tissue degradation post mortem. At 4 days post infection (dpi; equivalent to 5 days post fertilisation, dpf), all surviving zebrafish larvae were culled.

sec.title: Anti-nitrotyrosine Staining
sec.p: 1 dpi embryos were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS overnight in 4°C. Nitrotyrosine levels were labelled using a rabbit polyclonal anti-nitrotyrosine antibody (06-284; Merck Millipore) and were detected using Alexa-633 conjugated goat-anti-rabbit secondary antibody (Invitrogen Life Technologies) imaged using line-scanning confocal microscopy, as previously described (Elks et al., 2013, 2014).

sec.title: Microscopy and Quantification of Anti-nitrotyrosine
sec.p: For C. albicans SC5314 and car1Δ, brightfield images were taken using an inverted Leica DMi8 with a 40x lens and a Hamamatsu OrcaV4 camera. Stained embryos were imaged on a Leica DMi8 inverted microscope with a Leica TCS-SPE line-scanning confocal for imaging with a 40x lens. For quantification purposes, acquisition settings were kept the same across the groups. Corrected fluorescence intensity was calculated using Image J measurements assessing the cell fluorescence of individual cells corrected for cell size and background fluorescence of the image (Elks et al., 2013, 2014).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All data were analysed using GraphPad Prism 9.5.1 1 (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, California, USA, www.graphpad.com). Nitrotyrosine staining data was analysed with Kruskal-Wallis test, with Dunn’s multiple comparisons test. Nitrotyrosine staining data for proximal and distal RNS levels was analysed with 2-way ANOVA, with Sidák’s multiple comparison test. Survival curves were analysed with Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test, with Bonferroni correction. The p values shown are: ns=not significant, *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001, ****p<0.0001

sec.title: C. albicans infection suppresses neutrophil RNS production
sec.p: C. albicans has previously been demonstrated to modulate host innate immune responses, by suppressing production of ROS and RNS by macrophages in vitro (Wellington, Dolan and Krysan, 2009; Collette, Zhou and Lorenz, 2014). In zebrafish, we have previously shown that RNS, identified using an anti-nitrotyrosine antibody, is predominantly produced in neutrophils, both in resting/mock infected individuals (Elks et al., 2014) and to an elevated level after bacterial infection with Mycobacterium marinum (Elks et al., 2013). We aimed to establish if C. albicans is capable of modulating neutrophil RNS in an in vivo zebrafish model. 1 day post fertilisation (dpf) zebrafish larvae were infected in the caudal vein with either live C. albicans, heat killed C. albicans or a mock infected (PVP) control. At 24 hours post infection (hpi), zebrafish larvae were fixed and stained with an anti-nitrotyrosine antibody as a measure of host neutrophil RNS production. In mock infected (PVP) controls there was a basal level of anti-nitrotyrosine levels in neutrophils (Elks et al., 2013, 2014). Compared to the PVP control, C. albicans TT21-dTomato caused a 90.0% (p<0.0001) reduction in the corrected fluorescence intensity of nitrotyrosine staining (Figure 1A-B). Heat-killed C. albicans TT21-dTomato had an intermediate level of RNS suppression, between PVP (PVP=5.17, heat-killed C. albicans TT21-dTomato=2.47; p<0.0001) and live C. albicans infection (C. albicans TT21-dTomato=0.52, heat-killed C. albicans TT21-dTomato=2.47; p<0.0001). Similar phenotypes of RNS suppression were observed in infection with live and heat-killed C. albicans SN148 GFP, suggesting the effect is not strain specific (Figure S1). Hence, we used these fluorescence strains interchangeably, depending on the colour combinations required for each experiment. Together these data show that C. albicans suppresses neutrophil RNS production in vivo, while heat-killed C. albicans is capable of generating an intermediate level of RNS suppression.

sec.title: Suppression of neutrophil RNS by C. albicans occurs both proximally and distally to the infection site
sec.p: To determine whether neutrophils with reduced RNS need to be proximal to C. albicans infection, a local hindbrain ventricle C. albicans infection was performed, with RNS production measured both at the site of infection in the hindbrain and a distal, uninfected site in the caudal haematopoietic tissue (CHT). C. albicans caused a significant decrease in nitrotyrosine levels in both proximal neutrophils in the hindbrain (PVP=2.38, C. albicans=0.52; p<0.0001) and distal neutrophils in the CHT (PVP=2.59, C. albicans=0.71; p<.0001) compared to PVP control (Figure 2A-C). Hence, live C. albicans is capable of causing both a proximal and distal suppression of neutrophil RNS, suggestive of the influence of a secreted factor. Heat-killed C. albicans caused an intermediate RNS reduction in the hindbrain but had no effect on RNS in distal neutrophils in the CHT region, suggesting that multiple mechanisms may reduce neutrophil RNS that differ between proximal and distal regulation. Boiled C. albicans had no effect on neutrophil RNS at either location, implying that a secreted factor regulating neutrophil RNS may be a protein (that does not function once denatured). Together, these results suggest that C. albicans may have multiple mechanisms of neutrophil RNS suppression, some which act locally and others which act more distally.

sec.title: C. albicans arginase, CAR1, plays a role in the suppression of neutrophil RNS
sec.p: Host RNS levels are controlled by a balance of two enzymes that share the substrate L-arginine, iNOS and arginase. iNOS is the enzyme responsible for RNS production and arginase, shunts the metabolism of L-arginine away from RNS towards L-ornithine production (Bansal and Ochoa, 2003). Fungi are known to produce enzymes with similar functions in nitric oxide production, for example C. albicans produces its own version of arginase, CAR1 (Schaefer et al., 2020). We therefore hypothesised that C. albicans arginase interferes with the host arginase-iNOS axis, resulting in neutrophil RNS suppression. 1 dpf zebrafish were infected with C. albicans car1Δ or its parental strain C. albicans SC5314 and RNS production was measured at 24 hpi by anti-nitrotyrosine staining. C. albicans car1Δ infection decreased neutrophil RNS production compared to PVP (p<0.0001) (Figure 3A-B). The RNS produced after live C. albicans car1Δ infection was significantly different from live C. albicans SC5314 (p<0.05), heat-killed C. albicans SC5314 (p<0.0001) and heat-killed C. albicans car1Δ (p<0.0001), Heat-killed C. abicans car1Δ was not significantly different from heat-killed C. albicans SC5314 (p>0.9999), suggesting an active component is responsible for differences observed in live C. albicans. C. albicans car1Δ caused an intermediate level of RNS suppression between live C. albicans SC5314 and heat-killed C. albicans (Figure 3A-B), indicating that CAR1 plays a partial role in suppression of neutrophil RNS.

sec.title: Hif-1α is protective against C. albicans infection in a neutrophil-dependent manner
sec.p: Hif-1α is a transcription factor with known roles in regulation of innate immunity (McGettrick and O’Neill, 2020) and has previously been shown to be protective against Mycobacterium marinum infection in vivo by increasing neutrophil RNS levels (Elks et al., 2013; Hammond, Lewis and Elks, 2020). We aimed to stabilise Hif-1α in C. albicans infected zebrafish embryos, in order to restore innate immune responses and increase host survival in C. albicans infection.

1 cell stage zebrafish embryos were injected with phenol red (solvent control, PR), dominant negative hif-1α (DN1) or dominant active hif-1α (DA1) RNA, then infected systemically with C. albicans TT21-dTomato infection at 30 hpf. Mortality was measured over the following 4 days. DA1 injected embryos had significantly greater survival across 4 days than both PR (p<0.01) and DN1 (p<0.001) injected larvae (Figure 4A-B), suggesting Hif-1α stabilisation is host protective in C. albicans infection.

Neutrophils play an essential role in innate immune control of invasive candidiasis (Desai and Lionakis, 2018). Brothers et al. showed neutrophils are responsible for killing of C. albicans, whereas macrophages internalised, but did not kill, C. albicans in vivo (Brothers et al., 2013). Therefore, we hypothesised that the protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation was mediated by neutrophils. To assess the impact of Hif-1α stabilisation on macrophage-mediated immunity, we depleted the macrophage population by injection of clodronate liposomes (van Rooijen and Hendrikx, 2010) at 30 hpf or PBS liposomes as a negative control, leading to a significant depletion of the macrophage population (Figure S3). 1 cell stage embryos were injected with DA1 or PR control. At 30 hpf, embryos were injected into the caudal vein with clodronate liposomes or PBS liposomes followed by infection with 100cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato at 2 dpf. Both groups of PBS liposome injected larvae had greater survival than clodronate liposome, macrophage depleted, siblings. DA1 was protective in both the presence or depletion of macrophages, with clodronate liposome larvae having greater survival than PR clodronate liposome embryos (Figure 4C; p<0.0001), indicating that the host-protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation is not dependent on the presence of macrophages.

Next, we aimed to establish if neutrophils were responsible for the protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation in C. albicans infection. We injected 1 cell stage zebrafish embryos with a csf3r morpholino (Ellett et al., 2011) to deplete neutrophil numbers in 2 dpf zebrafish larvae (Figure S4). Csf3r morpholino injection led to a significant decrease in survival of 100cfu C. albicans infected larvae, in both PR and DA1 injected fish (Fig 4D). DA1 + csf3r larvae had lower survival compared to PR + csf3r larvae, showing a loss of the protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation in neutrophil ablated larvae (Figure 4D) and demonstrating that the protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation is neutrophil dependent.

sec.title: Host protective effect of Hif-1α is RNS-dependent
sec.p: Hif-1α stabilisation has previously been shown to increase RNS production in zebrafish neutrophils (Elks et al., 2013). We hypothesised that the host protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation in C. albicans infection was due to increased neutrophil RNS production. Therefore, we investigated the effect of dominant active hif-1α (DA1) on neutrophil behaviours during C. albicans infection. DA1 did not alter the recruitment of neutrophils to the site of a local C. albicans infection compared to phenol red (PR) injected controls (Figure S5), implying a change in neutrophil behaviour, not neutrophil numbers, is responsible for the protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation. In anti-nitrotyrosine stained larvae, DA1/PVP caused a doubling in nitrotyrosine levels compared to PR/PVP, mock injected larvae (Figure 5A-B; PR/PVP=16.36, DA1/PVP=33.25; p<0.0001) as previously described (Elks et al., 2013). While C. albicans reduced nitrotyrosine levels in PR control injected embryos, DA1 injection restored nitrotyrosine levels in C. albicans infected larvae to comparable levels of uninfected larvae (Fig 5A-B).

To demonstrate that this restoration of RNS in Hif-1α stabilisation is responsible for the host protective effect in C. albicans infection, we inhibited production of RNS pharmacologically, using L-NIL, and genetically, using nos2a+b (zebrafish iNOS) double CRISPR-Cas9 knockdown ("CRISPants"; Moore et al., 1994; Isles et al., 2019). L-NIL treatment did not impact the growth of C. albicans outside of the host in vitro (Figure S6). PR + L-NIL larvae had reduced survival compared to PR + dH2O (drug solvent control) treated larvae (Figure 5C), demonstrating the importance of RNS in C. albicans control. DA1 + L-NIL treated larvae did not have a significant survival advantage compared to either PR + dH2O or PR + L-NIL groups (Figure 5C), indicative of iNOS inhibition removing the host protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation. Nos2ab double CRISPants were shown to inhibit nitrotyrosine production in PVP injected zebrafish (Figure S7). DA1 with nos2ab CRISPants no longer had increased survival compared to PR + tyr sgRNA (tyrosinase CRISPant control; Isles et al., 2019) larvae, supporting that RNS production by nos2 is responsible for the host protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation (Figure 5D). Together these data demonstrate that the Hif-1α stabilisation is host-protective via a neutrophil- (Fig 4) and RNS-dependent (Fig 5) mechanism.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The increasing prevalence of antifungal resistance worldwide highlights the importance of discovering new antifungal targets or host directed therapies capable of improving disease outcomes. Here, we have shown that Hif-1α stabilisation represents a potential host directed therapy capable of restoring the neutrophil RNS response to C. albicans infection.

We first demonstrated that C. albicans can suppress neutrophil RNS production in vivo. Collette et al. previously showed C. albicans suppresses RNS production in murine bone marrow derived macrophages in vitro (Collette, Zhou and Lorenz, 2014), which is supported by a variety of sources showing suppression of ROS by C. albicans in vitro (Frohner et al., 2009; Wellington, Dolan and Krysan, 2009). While previous publications have demonstrated RNS suppression in macrophages, our data demonstrates an effect in neutrophils. Human neutrophils produce higher levels of RNS than macrophages (Muijsers et al., 2001), as is the case in zebrafish larvae, suggesting our findings may reflect the human RNS response to C. albicans making zebrafish a useful in vivo model to investigate the immune response in these difficult to study ex vivo, short-lived cells.

We showed C. albicans suppression of neutrophil RNS occurs both proximally at the site of infection and also at distal sites. Investigations using in vitro models have been unable to fully answer questions about host-C. albicans interactions in the context of a whole organism. Previous work has suggested direct contact between C. albicans and macrophages is required for RNS suppression and that an unidentified secreted factor plays a role (Collette, Zhou and Lorenz, 2014). Our findings do not preclude a suppression effect from direct contact between C. albicans and neutrophils, but suggest that direct contact is not a requirement and that suppression involves the secretion of a factor, allowing suppression of distal neutrophil RNS. Our in vivo model suggests that C. albicans has a secreted mechanism of RNS suppression which is capable of having effects large distances (millimetres) across an organism. This raises new questions about the role of C. albicans in the development of polymicrobial coinfections in immune compromised patients. This secreted factor is likely to be a protein as boiling C. albicans, resulting in denaturation of proteins, inhibits the distal suppression of neutrophil RNS. Pathogen-specific secreted compounds are a rich source for potential biomarkers of infection (Stastna and Van Eyk, 2012). Further research into the specific molecule responsible for suppressing neutrophil RNS distally is required to determine its suitability to act as a biomarker of C. albicans infection. The intermediate phenotype of RNS suppression by heat-killed C. albicans hints at multiple mechanisms of neutrophil RNS suppression by C. albicans. Current literature supports the idea of multiple mechanisms of suppression. C. albicans SOD5 has been associated with degradation of antimicrobial ROS in vitro (Frohner et al., 2009), C. albicans chitin induces host arginase-1 activity, decreasing RNS production (Wagener et al., 2017), YHB1 is able to detoxify RNS (Hromatka, Noble and Johnson, 2005) and Collette et al. identified an unknown, small secreted molecule capable of suppressing RNS (Collette, Zhou and Lorenz, 2014). The diversity of proteins and genes associated with decreased RNS production correlates with our hypothesis that multiple mechanisms of RNS suppression exist. Further investigation could aim to establish which, if any, mechanism contributes the most to host RNS suppression, and if any mechanisms can be targeted to downregulate the suppressive effect. Alternative explanations may be that heat-killing is partially denaturing fungal proteins, reducing activity of the hypothesised secreted protein, or that heat-killing is damaging the fungal cell wall, resulting in exposure of chitin, which is known to decrease RNS production (Wagener et al., 2017).

Here, we identify that C. albicans arginase is one such mechanism involved in the suppression of host RNS production. CAR1 is the only known arginase gene in the C. albicans genome, encoding a cytosolic arginase (Schaefer et al., 2020). Fungal arginase may be interfering with the host arginase-iNOS balance, resulting in reduced iNOS activity and RNS suppression. The modest decrease in neutrophil RNS production after infection with the CAR1 mutant suggests that C. albicans arginase production may not be the predominant RNS reducing mechanism, but additive strategies of neutrophil RNS suppression by C. albicans may underlie their success at the large overall suppression of neutrophil RNS observed locally and distally.

We have demonstrated that Hif-1α stabilisation has a protective effect in C. albicans infection in zebrafish embryos, via a neutrophil-mediated, RNS-dependent mechanism. Neutrophils are the primary innate immune cell responsible for killing Candida spp. (Brown, 2011), supporting our conclusion that neutrophil suppression is an important strategy of C. albicans during infection that, if rescued, could represent an exciting therapeutic opportunity. RNS has well characterised, highly candidacidal effects (Rementería, García-Tobalina and Sevilla, 1995; Vazquez-Torres et al., 1995; Tillmann, Gow and Brown, 2011; Navarathna, Lionakis and Roberts, 2019). Similarly, Macherla et al. revealed NO-releasing nanoparticles inhibit the growth of C. albicans in vitro and in vivo (Macherla et al., 2012). Hence, upregulation of neutrophil RNS production, following Hif-1α stabilisation, is a potential mechanism that could be targeted therapeutically to improve immune candidacidal activity. We have previously demonstrated Hif-1α stabilisation protects against M. marinum infection in a similar manner (Elks et al., 2013), suggesting Hif-1α stabilisation could offer protective effect against multiple and different groups of pathogens (fungi and bacteria) where neutrophil-mediated immune responses are subverted.

Our data indicates that Hif-1α stabilisation is able to overcome C. albicans suppression of neutrophil RNS, conferring a neutrophil-mediated, nitric oxide-dependent protective effect in vivo. Hence, Hif-1α stabilisation has potential as a host directed therapeutic strategy to aid in the treatment of C. albicans infections, following further validation in human systems. We also begin to determine the mechanisms underlying RNS suppression by C. albicans. Identification of specific proteins, genes or compounds responsible for RNS suppression could point towards new potential antifungal targets or prospective biomarkers to aid the diagnosis and treatment of C. albicans infections.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank The BSU Aquarium Team for fish care and the IICD Technical Team for practical assistance (University of Sheffield). We would like to thank Professor Neil Gow (University of Exeter) and Dr Robert Wheeler (University of Maine) for kindly providing Candida strains.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: A.L. and P.M.E. are funded by a Sir Henry Dale Fellowship, jointly funded by the Wellcome Trust and the Royal Society (Grant Number 105570/Z/14/A) held by P.M.E. T.B.B is supported by a studentship from the MRC Discovery Medicine North (DiMeN) Doctoral Training Partnership (MR/N013840/1). F.R.H. and P.T.S. were funded by a University of Sheffield PhD scholarship. S.C. was supported by a BBSRC White Rose DTP studentship (BB/M011151/1). S.A.J. was supported by Medical Research Council and Department for International Development Career Development Award Fellowship (MR/J009156/1). Zebrafish infection work was performed in The Wolfson Laboratories for Zebrafish Models of Infection (The Wolfson Foundation/Royal Society grant number WLR\R1\170024) at the University of Sheffield.

fn.p: Conceived and designed the experiments: TBB, FRH, PTS, AL, SC, AMC, PME. Performed the experiments: TBB, FRH, PTS, AL. Generation of Candida strains: SC, KRA, SAJ. Analysed the data: TBB, FRH, PTS, AL, AMC, PME. Wrote and drafted the manuscript: TBB, FRH, PTS, AL, AMC, PME.
The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.

caption.title: C. albicans suppressed neutrophil RNS production in vivo.
caption.p: (A) Anti-nitrotyrosine fluorescence at 24 hpi following injection of PVP, live C. albicans TT21-dTomato or heat-killed C. albicans TT21-dTomato into the caudal vein at 30 hpf. N=96-108 neutrophils from 16-18 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Kruskal-Wallis test, then Dunn’s multiple comparisons test. ****p<0.0001.
(B) Representative images of PVP, C. albicans TT21-dTomato and heat-killed C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos at 24 hpi. Scale bars = 50 μm.

caption.title: C. albicans suppression of RNS occurs proximally and distally to site of infection.
caption.p: (A) 1 dpf zebrafish were injected with PVP, C. albicans, heat-killed C. albicans or boiled C. albicans, into the hindbrain ventricle. At 24 hpi, embryos were fixed and stained with anti-nitrotyrosine primary antibody and goat-anti-rabbit Alexa-633 secondary antibody. Zebrafish were then imaged at the hindbrain and CHT regions and anti-nitrotyrosine fluorescence was quantified.

(B) Anti-nitrotyrosine fluorescence at 24 hpi following injection of PVP, C. albicans, heat-killed C. albicans or boiled C. albicans into the hindbrain ventricle. N=90 neutrophils from 15 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by 2-way ANOVA, then Sidák’s multiple comparisons test. ns=not significant, *p<0.05, ****p<0.0001
(C) Representative images of anti-nitrotyrosine stained 24 hpi zebrafish embryos at proximal and distal sites.

caption.title: C. albicans car1Δ has a role in suppression of neutrophil RNS.
caption.p: (A) Anti-nitrotyrosine fluorescence at 24 hpi following injection of PVP, C. albicans SC5314, heat-killed C. albicans SC5314, C. albicans car1Δ or heat-killed C. albicans car1Δ into the caudal vein. N=144 neutrophils from 24 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Kruskal-Wallis test, with Dunn’s multiple comparisons tests. *p<0.05, ****p<0.0001.
(B) Representative images of anti-nitrotyrosine stained embryos. Dashed lines show C. albicans. Scale bars = 50 μm.

caption.title: Hif-1α stabilisation is protective against C. albicans infection.
caption.p: (A) Survival of C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos following injection with dominant active hif-1α (DA1), dominant negative hif-1α (DN1) RNA or phenol red (PR) solvent control. Mortality was measured daily. N=102-103 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test with Bonferroni correction. **p<0.01, ****p<0.0001.
(B) Representative image of 200 cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryo at 24 hpi. Scale bar = 1000 μm.

(C) Survival curve of 100 cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos following injection with DA1 or PR, then treatment with PBS or clodronate liposomes. Mortality was measured daily. N=102-103 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test with Bonferroni correction. ****p<0.0001.

(D) Survival curve of 100 cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos following injection with PR or DA1 and control or csf3r morpholino. Mortality was measured daily. N=135 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test with Bonferroni correction. *p<0.05, **p<0.01.

caption.title: The host protective effect of Hif-1α stabilisation is RNS-dependent.
caption.p: (A) Anti-nitrotyrosine fluorescence at 24 hpi in PR and DA1 injected fish, following injection of PVP or 500 cfu C. albicans SN148 GFP. N=108 neutrophils from 18 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Kruskal-Wallis test, with Dunn’s multiple comparisons test. ns=not significant, ***p<0.001, ****p<0.0001
(B) Representative images of 1 dpi Tg(lyz:NTRmCherry) zebrafish embryos injected with PR or DA1 and infected with 500 cfu C. albicans SN148 GFP or PVP. Scale bars = 50 μm.

(C) Survival curve of 200 cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos following injection with PR or DA1, then treatment with dH2O or L-NIL. N=135 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test, with Bonferroni correction. **p<0.01, ***p<0.001.

(D) Survival curve of 200 cfu C. albicans TT21-dTomato infected zebrafish embryos following injection with PR or DA1 and tyr or nos2ab sgRNA. N=135 fish, obtained from 3 independent experiments. Error bars show SEM. Statistical significance determined by Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test, with Bonferroni correction. **p<0.01, ***p<0.001.

caption.title: List of C. albicans strains used in this study
